info.headline: Extreme Fire Danger issued April 11 at 2:49AM CDT by NWS Sioux Falls
info.description: ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT STARTING AT NOON TODAY THROUGH 9 PM FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR MUCH OF SOUTH CENTRAL AND SOUTHEAST SOUTH DAKOTA, NORTHWEST IOWA AND FAR NORTHEAST NEBRASKA... .DISCUSSION... Issued at 238 AM CDT Tue Apr 11 2023 Ample mixing within a favorable southwest flow today will allow anomalously warm mid level temperatures to the surface and result in widespread 80s to perhaps near 90 this afternoon, a bit cooler over areas with remaining snowcover. This mixing will also help pull down higher momentum air in the form of southwesterly winds gusting 30-35 mph, with isolated gusts closer to 40 mph not out of the question. Afternoon relative humidity values will fall quickly by late morning into critical threshold of 10-25%. Going Red Flag Warning still looks valid although did expand into Beadle County where it appears enough of the area has been snow free for long enough to allow for suitable fuel conditions. Counties bordering the Red Flag Warning may also see meteorological conditions approach critical thresholds, there is just higher uncertainty with fuel status given more recent snow melt or even remaining snowcover. Similar conditions are expected for Wednesday and Thursday, with perhaps a slight southeast shift where the main focus is as a boundary works into central and northeastern South Dakota. Will very likely need additional headlines for mid week but will handle one day at a time. People are urged to exercise extreme care with respect to outdoor activities that could cause grass fires. Avoid equipment that can cause sparks near dry grass or brush. Do not toss cigarettes on the ground. Report new fires quickly to the nearest fire department or law enforcement office. ...EXTREME FIRE DANGER... The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the extreme category this afternoon. Extreme weather conditions and very low moisture content of grasses, and other dry organic material on the ground, indicate that critical burning conditions exist. All fires have the potential to become large and spread quickly, becoming erratic with extreme behavioral characteristics. No outdoor burning should take place. OUTLOOK FOR WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON...The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the very high category. The grassland fire danger product reflects fire danger for native grasses. It is not intended for cured agricultural crops, nor will it reflect conditions in road ditches which have been mowed.
